bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Charles R. Reynolds, April 5, 1938

div1.p: Truby sends Reynolds a copy of a letter from Reed to himself. The letter reports Reed's successful infection of Kissinger with yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Charles R. Reynolds, April 5, 1938
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
IN REPLY REFER TO:
LETTERMAN GENERAL HOSPITAL
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
April 5, 1938
Major General C. R. Reynolds
The Surgeon General, U. S. Army
Washington, D. C.
My dear Reynolds:
div1.p:
In going over my old papers I came across a letter from
Major Walter Reed dated December 10, 1900, which seems to me to have
considerable historical value. I am therefore sending you herewith
photostat copies which you can send to the library or use as you think
best.

The letter seems important because it is probably the first
written report by Walter Reed of his first positive case at Camp
Lazear; also because of the statement that the Havana Board of Yellow
Fever, excepting Finlay, considered the mosquito theory a wild one.
This Board consisted of Dr. Juan Gitueras, Carlos Finlay, Major W. C.
Gorgas, and A. Diaz Albertini.

Camp Lazear was established during the time I was Post Sur-
geon at Camp Columbia and I had much to do with the work of getting the
camp ready. Experimental operations at the camp began on November 20.
All of the non-immunes were quarantined from all outside contact from
that date on.

Private Kissinger, the first case, was bitten by several of
Reed's ripe “birds” on December 5. At 11:30 P.M. on the 8th he had a
chill. On the next day Reed was positive that the case was Yellow
Fever. You will note that the envelope addressed to me was postmarked
at 8:00 A.M., December 10, 1900. I expect he was so thrilled and excited
that he was up at dawn that date ready for a great day with the skeptical
Yellow Fever experts.

“Cooke and Company” is the name we had for Dr. R. P. Cooke
and the two enlisted men who were then living (practically confined) in
the very small, poorly ventilated and filthy, infected bedding house. Dr.
Cooke was a very likeable young Virginian and Walter Reed and the rest
of us were very fond of him.

Further details of the experiment can, of course, be found in the
Board's published report entitled, “The Etiology of Yellow Fever - an
Additional Note.” This was read at the Pan-American Congress in Havana
on February 4, 1901. You will note that the facts given in the letter to
me are identical with the statements made in the official report although
that was published some time later.

I am sorry that I did not look up this letter long ago but,
while I knew it was among my papers, I did not realize until later its
possible historical value especially if there are any more controversies
over the matter in the future. I am, of course, pleased that this great
man took time out at that exciting moment of his successful career to give
me the very first news of his work at Camp Lazear. He was a real friend
of mine and thought enough of my professional ability and experience with
Yellow Fever to want me to be in Cienfuegos with his son who was then a
Second Lieutenant of the 10th Infantry. Otherwise, as I think you know, I
would have remained at Columbia Barracks with him as a member of his Board.
I left there on November 30, 1900, under rush orders for Cienfuegos.
Captain A. N. Stark relieved me at that time.

I have sent Generals Ireland and Kean copies of the Reed letter
and asked them what disposition I should make of the original. My first
thought was, of course, the library, but I will wait for suggestions from
you all. The Letterman made the photostats for me and they are mailing
them.

closer.signed:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
Brigadier General, U. S. Army
Retired
